# Xanthophyll

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Cryptoxanthin.png/400px-
Cryptoxanthin.png)](/wiki/File:Cryptoxanthin.png)

[](/wiki/File:Cryptoxanthin.png "Enlarge")

The chemical structure of [cryptoxanthin](/wiki/Cryptoxanthin "Cryptoxanthin")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Raw_egg.jpg/220px-
Raw_egg.jpg)](/wiki/File:Raw_egg.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Raw_egg.jpg "Enlarge")

The color of an egg yolk is from the xanthophyll carotenoids lutein and
zeaxanthin

This article is about Xanthophylls. For the compound xanthophyll, see
[lutein](/wiki/Lutein "Lutein").

**Xanthophylls** (originally **phylloxanthins**) are yellow
[pigments](/wiki/Pigment "Pigment") that occur widely in nature and form one
of two major divisions of the [carotenoid](/wiki/Carotenoid "Carotenoid")
group; the other division is formed by the [carotenes](/wiki/Carotene
"Carotene"). The name is from Greek _xanthos_ (ξανθός, "yellow")[1] and
_phyllon_ (φύλλον, "leaf"),[2] due to their formation of the yellow band seen
in early [chromatography](/wiki/History_of_chromatography "History of
chromatography") of [leaf](/wiki/Leaf "Leaf") pigments.

## Molecular
structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Xanthophyll&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Molecular structure")]

The molecular structure of xanthophylls is similar to that of
[carotenes](/wiki/Carotene "Carotene"), but xanthophylls contain
[oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen") atoms, while _carotenes_ are purely
hydrocarbons with no oxygen. Xanthophylls contain their oxygen either as
[hydroxyl groups](/wiki/Hydroxyl_group "Hydroxyl group") and/or as pairs of
hydrogen atoms that are substituted by oxygen atoms acting as a bridge
([epoxide](/wiki/Epoxide "Epoxide")). For this reason, they are more
[polar](/wiki/Polar_molecule "Polar molecule") than the purely hydrocarbon
carotenes, and it is this difference that allows their separations from
carotenes in many types of [chromatography](/wiki/Chromatography
"Chromatography"). Typically, carotenes are more orange in color than
xanthophylls.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Chromatography_of_chlorophyll_-
_Step_7.jpg/100px-Chromatography_of_chlorophyll_-
_Step_7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chromatography_of_chlorophyll_-_Step_7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chromatography_of_chlorophyll_-_Step_7.jpg "Enlarge")

Thin layer chromatography is used to separate components of a plant extract,
illustrating the experiment with plant pigments that gave chromatography its
name. Plant xanthophylls form the bright yellow band next to the green

## Occurrence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Xanthophyll&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Occurrence")]

Like other carotenoids, xanthophylls are found in highest quantity in the
[leaves](/wiki/Leaves "Leaves") of most green [plants](/wiki/Plants "Plants"),
where they act to modulate light energy and perhaps serve as a [non-
photochemical quenching](/wiki/Non-photochemical_quenching "Non-photochemical
quenching") agent to deal with triplet [chlorophyll](/wiki/Chlorophyll
"Chlorophyll") (an excited form of chlorophyll)[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], which
is overproduced at high light levels in photosynthesis. The xanthophylls found
in the bodies of animals, and in dietary animal products, are ultimately
derived from plant sources in the diet. For example, the yellow color of
chicken [egg](/wiki/Egg_\(biology\) "Egg \(biology\)") [yolks](/wiki/Yolk
"Yolk"), fat, and skin comes from ingested xanthophylls (primarily
[lutein](/wiki/Lutein "Lutein"), which is often added to chicken feed for this
purpose).

The yellow color of the human [macula lutea](/wiki/Macula_lutea "Macula
lutea") (literally, _yellow spot_) in the [retina](/wiki/Retina "Retina") of
the eye results from the [lutein](/wiki/Lutein "Lutein") and
[zeaxanthin](/wiki/Zeaxanthin "Zeaxanthin") it contains, both xanthophylls
again requiring a source in the human diet to be present in the eye. These
xanthophylls protect the eye from ionizing blue and ultraviolet light, which
they absorb. These two specific xanthophylls do not function in the mechanism
of sight, since they cannot be converted to [retinal](/wiki/Retinal "Retinal")
(also called retinaldehyde or [vitamin A](/wiki/Vitamin_A "Vitamin A")
aldehyde). Their arrangement is believed to be the cause of [Haidinger's
brush](/wiki/Haidinger%27s_brush "Haidinger's brush"), an [entoptic
phenomenon](/wiki/Entoptic_phenomenon "Entoptic phenomenon") that allows the
perception of the [polarization](/wiki/Polarization_\(waves\) "Polarization
\(waves\)") of light.

## Example
compounds[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Xanthophyll&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Example compounds")]

The group of xanthophylls includes (among many other compounds)
[lutein](/wiki/Lutein "Lutein"), [zeaxanthin](/wiki/Zeaxanthin "Zeaxanthin"),
[neoxanthin](/wiki/Neoxanthin "Neoxanthin"), [violaxanthin](/wiki/Violaxanthin
"Violaxanthin"), [flavoxanthin](/wiki/Flavoxanthin "Flavoxanthin"), and α- and
β-[cryptoxanthin](/wiki/Cryptoxanthin "Cryptoxanthin"). The latter compound is
the only known **xanthophyll** to contain a beta-ionone ring, and thus
β-[cryptoxanthin](/wiki/Cryptoxanthin "Cryptoxanthin") is the only xanthophyll
that is known to possess pro-vitamin A activity for mammals. Even then, it is
a vitamin only for plant-eating mammals that possess the enzyme to make
retinal from carotenoids that contain beta-ionone (some carnivores lack this
enzyme). In species other than mammals, certain xanthophylls may be converted
to hydroxylated retinal-analogues that function directly in vision. For
example, with the exception of certain flies, most insects use the xanthophyll
derived R-isomer of 3-hydroxyretinal for visual activities, which means that
β-[cryptoxanthin](/wiki/Cryptoxanthin "Cryptoxanthin") and other xanthophylls
(such as lutein and zeaxanthin) may function as forms of visual "vitamin A"
for them, while carotenes (such as beta carotene) do not.

## Xanthophyll
cycle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Xanthophyll&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Xanthophyll cycle")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Violaxanthin_cycle.png/400px-
Violaxanthin_cycle.png)](/wiki/File:Violaxanthin_cycle.png)

[](/wiki/File:Violaxanthin_cycle.png "Enlarge")

The xanthophyll cycle

The xanthophyll cycle involves the enzymatic removal of epoxy groups from
xanthophylls (e.g. [violaxanthin](/wiki/Violaxanthin "Violaxanthin"),
[antheraxanthin](/wiki/Antheraxanthin "Antheraxanthin"),
[diadinoxanthin](/wiki/Diadinoxanthin "Diadinoxanthin")) to create so-called
de-epoxidised xanthophylls (e.g. [diatoxanthin](/wiki/Diatoxanthin
"Diatoxanthin"), [zeaxanthin](/wiki/Zeaxanthin "Zeaxanthin")). These enzymatic
cycles were found to play a key role in stimulating energy dissipation within
light-harvesting antenna proteins by [non-photochemical quenching](/wiki/Non-
photochemical_quenching "Non-photochemical quenching")\- a mechanism to reduce
the amount of energy that reaches the photosynthetic reaction centers. Non-
photochemical quenching is one of the main ways of protecting against
[photoinhibition](/wiki/Photoinhibition "Photoinhibition").[3] In higher
plants, there are three carotenoid pigments that are active in the xanthophyll
cycle: violaxanthin, antheraxanthin, and zeaxanthin. During light stress,
violaxanthin is converted to zeaxanthin via the intermediate antheraxanthin,
which plays a direct photoprotective role acting as a lipid-protective [anti-
oxidant](/wiki/Anti-oxidant "Anti-oxidant") and by stimulating non-
photochemical quenching within light-harvesting proteins. This conversion of
violaxanthin to zeaxanthin is done by the enzyme violaxanthin de-epoxidase,
while the reverse reaction is performed by zeaxanthin epoxidase.[4]

In [diatoms](/wiki/Diatoms "Diatoms") and
[dinoflagellates](/wiki/Dinoflagellates "Dinoflagellates"), the xanthophyll
cycle consists of the pigment [diadinoxanthin](/wiki/Diadinoxanthin
"Diadinoxanthin"), which is transformed into [diatoxanthin](/wiki/Diatoxanthin
"Diatoxanthin") (diatoms) or [dinoxanthin](/wiki/Dinoxanthin "Dinoxanthin")
(dinoflagellates) under high-light conditions.[5]

Wright et al. (Feb 2011) found that, "The increase in zeaxanthin appears to
surpass the decrease in violaxanthin in spinach" and commented that the
discrepancy could be explained by "a synthesis of zeaxanthin from beta-
carotene", however they noted further study is required to explore this
hypothesis.[6]

## Food sources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Xanthophyll&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Food sources")]

Xanthophylls are found in all young leaves and in [etiolated](/wiki/Etiolation
"Etiolation") leaves. Examples of other rich sources include papaya, peaches,
prunes, and squash, which contain lutein diesters.[7][8][9]
